message_1: A smartphone manufacturer claims that their latest model has a battery life of around 30 hours in normal use. To test this claim, a sample of 50 users used the phone and recorded the battery life in hours. The average battery life of the sample was found to be 28.5 hours with a standard deviation of 4.7 hours. Find a 95% confidence interval for the true mean battery life of the phone.
message_2:
To find the 95% confidence interval for the true mean battery life of the phone, we will use the formula:

CI = x̄ ± (t * (s / √n))

where:
CI = confidence interval
x̄ = sample mean (28.5 hours)
t = t-score for a 95% confidence interval with 49 degrees of freedom (df = n - 1)
s = sample standard deviation (4.7 hours)
n = sample size (50 users)

First, we need to find the t-score. For a 95% confidence interval and 49 degrees of freedom, the t-score is approximately 2.0096 (you can find this value using a t-distribution table or an online calculator).

Now we can plug in the values into the formula:

CI = 28.5 ± (2.0096 * (4.7 / √50))

CI = 28.5 ± (2.0096 * (4.7 / 7.071))

CI = 28.5 ± (2.0096 * 0.665)

CI = 28.5 ± 1.3364

So the 95% confidence interval for the true mean battery life of the phone is approximately (27.1636, 29.8364) hours. This means that we are 95% confident that the true mean battery life of the phone is between 27.1636 hours and 29.8364 hours.
